Authors:
Timothy J. Gallaher, Dean C. Adams, Lakshmi Attigala, Sean
Vincent Burke, Joseph M. Craine, Melvin R Duvall, Phillip C. Klahs, Emma
Sherratt, William P. Wysocki, Lynn G Clark
Title:
Leaf shape and size evolution suggests an important role for
partial-shade ecotone habitats in the diversification of the grasses
(Poaceae)
Keywords:
Adaptation, C4 photosynthesis, geometric morphometrics,
grasslands, macroecology, phylogeny, vein architecture
Abstract:
Although most grasses today are associated with open
habitats such as grasslands and savanna, the first grasses likely
evolved in shady forest ecosystems. The morphology of grass leaves is a
strong indicator of the habitat in which they are found and shifts from
shaded to open habitats were likely marked by distinctive changes in
leaf shape or size. We modelled relationships between leaf shape, size,
habitat, climate and photosynthetic pathway in a phylogenetic framework
to test whether partial-shade environments served as transitional zones
between forests and grasslands and to evaluate drivers of leaf shape and
size evolution. Length and width covary with precipitation and solar
irradiance resulting in smaller leaves in drier, higher irradiance
habitats but without significant changes in overall shape. The shape is
strongly associated with shade levels resulting in more ovate leaves in
closed habitats and more linear leaves in open habitats. Evidence for
the ancestral state of the family is equivocal between full and
partial-shade; however, partial-shade habitats such as forest margins
along with a lanceolate leaf shape likely served as important
transitional habitat and morphology respectively for evolution across
forest-grassland biome boundaries.
